paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data.

patients.phenotype: Late-onset cardiomyopathy, more commonly in men

individual_records.evidence_sentence: This variant is most often detected in individuals of African descent, with approximately 3% of African-Americans carrying at least one copy of the gene.
This variant is most often detected in individuals of African descent, with approximately 3% of African-Americans carrying at least one copy of the gene.

functional_data.summary: The variant is known to negatively impact the function of the TTR protein, resulting in amyloidosis.

variants.segregation_data: Yes, it segregates with disease in families.
key_quotes: The most common variant associated with amyloidosis was p.Val142Ile (allele frequency 0.001).
This variant is most often detected in individuals of African descent.

patients.phenotype: Cardiac amyloidosis and autonomic and peripheral neuropathy

individual_records.phenotype_details: Cardiac amyloidosis and autonomic and peripheral neuropathy
individual_records.evidence_sentence: This variant is associated with cardiac amyloidosis as well as autonomic and peripheral neuropathy.

functional_data.summary: The variant is known to negatively impact the function of the TTR protein, resulting in amyloidosis.

variants.segregation_data: Yes, it segregates with disease in families.
variants.additional_notes: Age of onset in seventh decade of life.
key_quotes: This variant is associated with cardiac amyloidosis as well as autonomic and peripheral neuropathy.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Our study also identified two individuals with another known amyloidogenic variant, c.239C>T(p.Thr80Ile), with an allele frequency of 0.00007.
Our study also identified two individuals with another known amyloidogenic variant, c.239C>T(p.Thr80Ile), with an allele frequency of 0.00007.

functional_data.summary: Qualifies as a dense hot-spot and pathogenic mutation by Varsome.

variants.additional_notes: Phenotype associated with this variant has not been previously reported.
key_quotes: It qualifies as a dense hot-spot and pathogenic mutation by Varsome, but there are no reports of the clinical manifestation.

tables_processed.table_caption: Phenotypes of known amyloidogenic TTR variants with alleles identified in the Saudi population

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data extracted from the main text and tables.
